bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, November 2, 1940

div1.p: Andrus solicits commentary from Truby on his article. He mentions previous correspondence with Hench and states that he does not know the details of how Kissinger and Moran became volunteers.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, November 2, 1940
div1.opener:
J.H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
11-2-40.
Addresses of others of Det. H. C
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
In some respects your letter of the thirtieth is a disappointment.
I hoped you would take off your gloves and frankly criticise my
“guinea pig” chapter. While I have made every possible effort
to check the known facts, I have indulged in conjecture in quite
a number of instances and it would be too much to hope that I have
always hit the bulls-eye.

I know this is asking a lot but my only reason for writing this
episode at all is to give the FACTS and, when records must be de-
parted from, I want to feel certain that my conclusions are reason-
able and logical. Not only to me - but to OTHERS and, espec-
ially, to anyone who knows what it is all about as well as you do.

When I read, “I think your article is splendid”, and you let it go
at that, I fear you picture me in bed ready to burst in tears at
anything but praise. Most of my working life has been spent as
an advertising manager. I have spent hours of time and gallons
of perspiration planning an advertising campaign - or advertising
copy - only to sometimes see it torn to shreads by some of the
higher officials of my company. I can still “take it” so, wont
you get out your axe and go after my story? . . .
As for keeping the copy I sent you - you may have it.
Referring to specific items in your letter:

Page 27. Am enclosing a letter from the Surgeon General's office
from which you will see it refers to STEWARD John Neate. While
this does not indicate his rank at the time he was in Cuba, I am
reasonably certain he was, then, a steward and not acting.

Was very much interested in what you say about the dedication of a
building to the memory of Dr. Lazear and am looking forward to the
printed proceedings you promise to send me. Back in March, 1938,
I had an exchange of correspondence with Dr. P. S. Hench.
He had become interested in my case through Moran and seemed to
think the Mayo Clinic might be able to do something for me.
It ended when I sent him my version of my case history and it was
supplemented by a letter from my son, an M. D. Upon receipt of
these letters, he wrote that he was going to Europe and would com-
municate with me upon his return. There it ended.

Thank you for telling me about General Sternberg's book and the
reference to me therein. I will try to get it.

Foot-bridge over railroad: I do not recall this bridge at all but
you will find it described on the sketch of yellow fever hospital
made by Lambert, which I sent you a few days ago.

Your reference to the political situation voices my sentiments per-
fectly. From all I read and hear over the radio it would seem
that Willkie has made rapid progress during the last few days.
I am afraid, however, that Roosevelt has subsidized too many voters
to lose the election.

I realize that Hoover has been too thoroughly “smeared” to be elect-
ed to any office but I feel he is, by training and experience, the
best presidential timber in the country.

I sometimes wonder if our democracy can endure when so many voters
believe the most fantastic fairy tales if only they are charmingly
voiced. . .

Am returning the exchange of correspondence between General Kean
and yourself. I found this extremely interesting and did,
indeed, find several things explained that I have been wondering
about. I did not realize that more than one or two had attempt-
ed to climb on the honor roll band wagon. Doesn't that seem
strange when it is remembered that the honor roll was not created
until late in 1929?

No, General, I have not been worn out by this correspondence.
As I intimated in a previous letter, it deals with a subject in
which I am very much interested and helps to pass time very
pleasantly.
With kindest regards and every good wish,

closer.seg:
Postscript: I know nothing of the details about how Kissinger and
Moran came to volunteer for innoculation except what Moran wrote me.
I have wondered why I have had no reply to my letter asking his
permission to send his letter to you. As you say he was to be
present at the dedication of the Lazear memorial, that probably
explains it. - JHA.
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
